awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Aerodynamic-aeroacoustic performance of poroelastic wings inspired by the silent plumage of owls
awd_abstract_narration:
Owls are extraordinary predators that are able to suppress their aerodynamic noise generation and achieve effectively silent flight over a broad frequency range, which includes the sensitive hearing ranges of owls, their prey, and humans. The poroelastic fringe adaptation of owls is believed to contribute to this broadband noise suppression by modifying the trailing-edge noise mechanism that sets the minimum noise level of many engineering designs, such as computer fans, propulsors, commercial airframes, and wind turbines. Many applications for which weaker edge noise is sought are also constrained by, for example, aerodynamic performance or stability metrics related to the integrated pressure across these fluid-loaded structures (e.g., lift or moment). Furthermore, it is clear that changes to the trailing-edge geometry and compliance to improve acoustic performance should entail an aerodynamic performance penalty. In this scenario, the unsteady acoustic and hydrodynamic fields must be considered together. At present, guidance towards a more complete understanding of their interaction for finite-chord and finite-span structures with variable porous and elastic properties is lacking. Furthermore, there is little empirical support for the predicted aerodynamic and aeroacoustic effects of poroelastic edges. The principal aim of this project is to address these shortcomings through a series of analytical and numerical model problems coordinated with experimental measurement to elucidate the unsteady loading and noise generation of thin fluid-loaded structures with graded poroelastic properties. 

This project addresses the above technical shortcomings through an interactive theoretical-experimental program that distinguishes itself in no fewer than three ways: (i) construction of analytical and numerical frameworks to predict turbulence noise generation by graded poroelastic structures, from first principles; (ii) experimental validation of acoustic scaling laws for poroelastic edges, without background flow noise; and (iii) development of a glider to measure wing noise on the fly in a manner consistent with how owls hear their self-noise. The modeling and validation efforts aim to transform a biologically-inspired noise solution into a rational paradigm for passive aerodynamic noise control in low-speed flows and to create an experimental platform for future bionic owl noise-reduction studies. This project will also include K-12 educational outreach with the DaVinci Science Center (Allentown, PA), as well as integrate undergraduate research involvement through the Lehigh Biosystems Dynamics Summer Institute (in partnership with Northampton Community College) and through a design-build-fly competition between Lehigh and Penn State.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Applied Research Laboratory Penn State University

por.por_cntn:
This project was motivated by the ability of owls to fly more silently than other birds.  The underlying hypothesis is that the unique structure of their wings alters the production of trailing-edge noise, a dominant noise source mechanism for lifting surfaces at low speed.  The unique wing structure includes both porosity and compliance.  Previous theoretical work describing poroelastic trailing edge noise is has predicted radiated noise attenuation, but empirical validation of many features of these predictions were lacking. 

The principal intellectual merit outcome was to perform measurements to which theoretical predictions could be validated.  Working with our collaborators at Lehigh University, the trailing edge noise problem was abstracted to the interaction of a vortex ring convecting past the edge of a large plate with a porous edge. This formulation permitted theoretical predictions with clear validation metrics.  The resulting experiments were conducted in still air, removing many of the background noise sources present in wind tunnel testing.  The confirmed many of the theoretical predictions, but some disagreement between theory and measurements suggests further refinements are warranted.  These results are of direct interest to biologists, and to engineers working in the areas of fluid mechanics, aerospace, energy, and heat transfer.

The principal broader impacts include the project?s broad interdisciplinary scope and research training of graduate students.  This grant supported two graduate students, one in Bioengineering, and the other in the Graduate Program in Acoustics.  In addition, ARL Penn state hosted a Lehigh University graduate student who learned signal analysis techniques and participated in research specific to our laboratory.

 


Last Modified: 02/15/2023
Modified by: Michael H Krane

Images (1 of )
  • Schematic of interaction between vortex ring and porous edge.
    Zachary Yoas, Huanshang Chen
    Copyrighted
    Michael H Krane
    Vortex/edge interaction
  • Sound power scaling law exponent n vs. plate porosity. Solid line shows theoretical prediction, symbols show measurement results as indicated.
    Zachary Yoas
    Copyrighted
    Michael H Krane
    Sound power scaling with porosity
  • Aeroacoustic source strength waveform at 4 values of plate porosity, as indicated.
    Zachary Yoas, Mitchell Swann
    Copyrighted
    Michael H Krane
    Sound source waveforms, with porosity
  • Variation of sound pressure directivity for 4 values of plate porosity. Agreement of theory to measurement is excellent for large and small porosity, but the transition from cardioid to dipole directivity is much more rapid than prediction.
    Zachary Yoas, Mitchell Swann
    Copyrighted
    Michael H Krane
    Sound pressure directivity, with porosity
